pr_title: Issue #6988: Sort XPath Results in Document Order

timeline.message: Issue #6988: Sort XPath results in Document Order
Issue #6988: Sort XPath results in Document Order
Issue #6988: Sort XPath results in Document Order

timeline.bodyText: @gaurabdg @timurt How often is compareOrder called for different queries? Is it a big impact that we have to calculate the depth each time it is called?
timeline.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText: @rnveach I can kind of cache the depth value for each node, as the two compared nodes least common ancestor is very near(because this ordering is required for xpath queries for nearby nodes mostly)  and will save a lot of computations.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText:
So I was right with my concern that it is called many times for 1 query?
I don't want to create more caches if they aren't really needed.
replies.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText: Yes, it will be called for each xpath result ordering
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText:
The order of cousins will be wrong. Consider
CLASS_DEF
   METHOD_DEF1
       VARIABLE_DEF1-1
       VARIABLE_DEF1-2
   METHOD_DEF2
       VARIABLE_DEF2-1
       VARIABLE_DEF2-2

The list of nodes for the xpath "//VARIABLE_DEF" will be VARIABLE_DEF1-1, VARIABLE_DEF2-1,VARIABLE_DEF2-2,VARIABLE_DEF1-2.
We still need some sort of recursion here. When the depth is different, the result is clear.
When the depth matches, there should be a check for order for the parent nodes (in case both nodes do not belong to the same parent).
replies.author: pbludov

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't this line be part of if (other != null) {?
timeline.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText: Spotbugs gave a warning for unchecked casting for that line, so to resolve that I put the check just before that, but I'll put them together now.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: gaurabdg

timeline.bodyText: Why is there a check for null? Does this not happen naturally?
timeline.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText: No, naturally such a case doesn't arise, so this was added to achieve 100% branch coverage.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText: If null isn't natural and doc doesn't say it can send a null then why do we have a check for it. I assume the branch was the null check? If it can never be null then the check is pointless and can be removed.
replies.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText: the if (other instanceof ElementNode) is required by Spotbugs otherwise it will throw an unchecked cast error for ((ElementNode) other).indexAmongSiblings. So, I will replace null with rootNode object instead to fail it and cover the branch.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: gaurabdg

timeline.bodyText: @gaurabdg interesting approach, but can we store this depth inside object to avoid unnecessary calculations
timeline.author: timurt

timeline.bodyText:
Could you also add more tests here

compare order between two sibling nodes
parent not with child or even grand child node
timeline.author: timurt

replies.bodyText: @gaurabdg please add tests
replies.author: timurt
gaurabdg
timurt

replies.bodyText: Okay, siblings one is done in the example provided by me in my previous comment. I'll create the parent-child test
replies.author: gaurabdg

timeline.bodyText:
could you please also one more test, to query many nodes and check that results are sorted in document order,
similar test I made for line/column approach here https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/7485/files#diff-39f05e8712ca7f402d8723874f834436R966
timeline.author: timurt

replies.bodyText: @gaurabdg please add test
replies.author: timurt

replies.bodyText: @timurt Many such document order tests are present in XpathMapperTest. Do we still need to add tests here?
replies.author: gaurabdg
timurt

timeline.bodyText: you need to check this.nodeDepth  == -1 and only then starting calculating current depth. Otherwise this method will make extra redundant calculations
timeline.author: timurt

timeline.bodyText:
@gaurabdg @rnveach
My suggestion was - we can set nodeDepth during constructing xpath tree
nodeDepth will field be of the AbstractNode class
RootNode.nodeDepth will be zero
and at this line we will have:
nodeDepth = parent.nodeDepth + 1;
and that's all, share your ideas
timeline.author: timurt

replies.bodyText: @timurt @rnveach I didn't know whether to touch other modules or not. It can be done and will be more efficient. So, shall I create a depth attribute of DetailASTImpl class and pass on this.depth + 1 while creating child nodes? Let me know what should be done, meanwhile I'll add the tests
replies.author: gaurabdg
timurt
gaurabdg

replies.bodyText:
@gaurabdg
We have two trees:

one is AST tree with DetailAST objects, used by almost all checks to validate rules
another one is Xpath tree with classes implementing NodeInfo(saxon) interface, this tree is used only for querying nodes using xpath queries

Xpath tree nodes have reference to corresponding AST tree nodes
Construction of the xpath tree starts with RootNode, as argument RootNode constructor takes root DetailAst object, and recursively traverse AST tree and creates corresponding Xpath nodes
For example for SuppressionXpathFilter, we create RootNode here,
Violation event TreeWalkerAuditEvent itself contains reference to rootAst, so we can create Xpath tree from it
is it clear? I know it is not obvious, so please ask questions
replies.author: timurt

replies.bodyText: @timurt Thanks a lot for clarifying. I will ask further as and when required while implementing the new approach.
replies.author: gaurabdg

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure ElementNodeTest is appropriate class for this method, please move it to XpathMapperTest
timeline.author: timurt

timeline.bodyText:
I executed this test with different compareOrder method implementation, it always passes, it is not ok
As far as I understand this depth approach, it should be fully correlate with line/column ordering.
It means for all nodes in getXpathItems(xpath, rootNode); the following condition is true:
node[i].lineNumber < node[j].lineNumber or (node[i].lineNumber = node[j].lineNumber and node[i].columnNumber < node[j].columnNumber) where i < j.
It is easier to write because all NodeInfo subclasses implement getLineNumber(), getColumnNumber() using real DetailAst values.
There is more difficult way to write this test:

get results from getXpathItems(xpath, rootNode);
convert them to DetailAST[] using convertToArray(List<NodeInfo> nodes) method
get rootAst from RootNode
traverse rootAst with DFS and check that all elements DetailAST[] appear in exact same order
timeline.author: timurt

replies.bodyText: Okay, I'll make the changes
replies.author: gaurabdg

timeline.bodyText: This test fails for the xpath "//METHOD_DEF/SLIST/*"
timeline.author: pbludov

replies.bodyText:
How about more depth?
CLASS_DEF0
  CLASS_DEF1
     METHOD_DEF1-1
         VARIABLE_DEF1-1-1
         VARIABLE_DEF1-1-2
     METHOD_DEF1-2
         VARIABLE_DEF1-2-1
         VARIABLE_DEF1-2-2
  CLASS_DEF2
     METHOD_DEF2-1
         VARIABLE_DEF2-1-1
         VARIABLE_DEF2-1-2
     METHOD_DEF2-2
         VARIABLE_DEF2-2-1
         VARIABLE_DEF2-2-2

Now all VARIABLE_DEFs are on 4th depth, their parents on 3rd depth.
We can not just compare order of METHOD_DEFs, we should go up till a common parent node.
replies.author: pbludov

replies.bodyText: @pbludov When the depth is same I have computed their common ancestor's indexAmongSiblings. Since the children to be compared are at the same level each call will have a time complexity of O(heightOfTree) i.e., logarithmic time and hence won't be much heavy.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText: @pbludov Please review.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText:
How about more depth?
CLASS_DEF0
  CLASS_DEF1
     METHOD_DEF1-1
         VARIABLE_DEF1-1-1
         VARIABLE_DEF1-1-2
     METHOD_DEF1-2
         VARIABLE_DEF1-2-1
         VARIABLE_DEF1-2-2
  CLASS_DEF2
     METHOD_DEF2-1
         VARIABLE_DEF2-1-1
         VARIABLE_DEF2-1-2
     METHOD_DEF2-2
         VARIABLE_DEF2-2-1
         VARIABLE_DEF2-2-2

Now all VARIABLE_DEFs are on 4th depth, their parents on 3rd depth.
We can not just compare order of METHOD_DEFs, we should go up till a common parent node.

Yes, I realized this case and deleted my comment just after a while and implemented the LCA approach.
replies.author: gaurabdg

timeline.bodyText: We check instance to be ElementNode but do a cast to AbstractNode. Shouldn't both be the same class?
timeline.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText:
@rnveach Yes, you are right, I forgot to change after a few changes in other code.
I've corrected it.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText:
@gaurabdg It looks like IntelliJ wants both to be AbstractNode. I don't see any parts of the code requiring it be ElementNode.
https://teamcity.jetbrains.com/viewLog.html?buildId=2866738&tab=Inspection&buildTypeId=Checkstyle_IdeaInspectionsPullRequest
replies.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText: Done.
replies.author: gaurabdg
